title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 07
author: Various
snippet: We drove up the glen, by Croalchapel; and my friend was allabsence, and inward rumination, and anticipated delight.

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 07
author: Various
snippet: We drove up the glen, by Croalchapel; and my friend was allabsence, and inward rumination, and anticipated delight.

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 04
author: Various
snippet: Seventeen! Irepeated, just seventeen!--and I urged on the pony instinctively, as ifhastening towards Croalchapel.

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 04
author: Various
snippet: He wasstill, unfortunately, within an hour's walk of Croalchapel, and lay,like a cat in a corner, watching his prey.

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 04
author: Various
snippet: Her mother had given her life at theexpense of her own; and her father, a shoemaker in the village ofCroalchapel, devoted his whole spare time to the education of Alice.

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 18
author: Alexander Leighton
snippet: The body of Ferguson was carried to Croalchapel; andthe two sons accompanied it, with many tears.

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 18
author: Alexander Leighton
snippet: The body of Ferguson was carried to Croalchapel; andthe two sons accompanied it, with many tears.

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 20
author: Alexander Leighton
snippet: OldBluntie caused a report to be conveyed to Clavers, whilst stationed atCroalchapel, in the neighbourhood, that a number of the friends of theCovenant, with old Cargill at their head, were to have a meeting, orconventicle, in a hollow glen, fifty yards south of the Linn.

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 20
author: Alexander Leighton
snippet: OldBluntie caused a report to be conveyed to Clavers, whilst stationed atCroalchapel, in the neighbourhood, that a number of the friends of theCovenant, with old Cargill at their head, were to have a meeting, orconventicle, in a hollow glen, fifty yards south of the Linn.

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 17
author: Alexander Leighton
snippet: Helen Palmer was originally from Cumberland; her parents were English, buther father had removed with Helen, an only daughter, whilst yet a child, tothe neighbourhood of Closeburn Castle, to a small village which still goesby the name of Croalchapel.
